ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: In math 305 I learned the basics of how to deal with measure theory. Still there seemed to be a gap between all the tiny details and my understanding of calculus from high school and math 120. This course helped fill in those gaps. Now I feel I much better understand the generalizations of integration and (to a lesser extent) differentiation.
basics in measure theory and functional analysis
Complex measures, convergence theorems, Hausdorff stuff, Caratheodory, Riesz Representation, Lebesgue-Radon-Nikodyn, L^p spaces, Banach spaces, etc.
Measure theory and basic functional analysis, including convergence theorem, constructing measure spaces, banach and hilbert spaces.

Reviewed a bit of content from 305, then hopped around Rudins book (Monotone Class Theorem, Product Measures, Regularity of Measures, Riesz Markov Kakatuni, norms, L^p space stuff, Hilbert Spaces, Riesz Representation and Lebesgue Radon Nikodym, and some differentiation)

I learnt about abstract measure spaces, L ^ p spaces, and Hilbert spaces. I really enjoyed the course as it is well structured, and the homework questions lend additional insight into the concepts in lectures. The workload is not too high, similar to that in MATH 305 I would imagine.
Basics of measure theory, Lp spaces, integration and some derivatives

Sigma algebras, measurable functions, positive measures, integration, classic theorems for integration (monotone convergence theorem, dominated convergence theorem, Fatou's lemma), outer measures, building Borel measures from distribution functions, monotone class theorem, product measure spaces, Fubini-Tonelli, regular measures, Riesz-Markov-Kakutani theorem, L^p spaces and basic functional analysis (Banach spaces, Hilbert spaces, orthonormal bases, etc.), Lebesgue-Radon-Nikodym theorem, and Lebesgue differentiation theorem.

Measure theory and integration
Analysis proof techniques
The course provided a comprehensive overview of the field of measure theory. I acquired a detailed knowledge of the core toos used in the field.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The strength of this class was that it set ambitious goals to cover a lot of material that is very interesting. I wish more attention were given to the second half of this material, because half of the class had already learned the first half of the material in math 305. Everything before product measures was mostly review although math 305 does not teach it in as much generality. I struggled to follow everything in the second half of the course so I wish that the whole entire course focused on the material covered in the second half. I guess the difficulty is that this class is also meant for graduate students as an introduction to measure theory, but this creates some redundancy for undergrads who are well prepared by Minsky's great teaching of 305.
lectures are crystal clear, well orgnized
The course falls in a weird spot between 305 and 325. In 305 with Minsky we had done around 2/5ths of the material covered in 320. Lectures were very dry and the textbook was even dryer.

Strength: Prof Wang is great at teaching. Her proofs are always clear and direct, and she always carefully explains any questions raised by students in class.
Weakness: Every time the grader just selects and grades part of the assignment. I know it has to do with a shortage of graders, but I hope we can get feedback on every homework questions.

Most lectures were usually just proving 4-5 new theorems or results without a pause, which was sometimes hard to keep up with. Luckily, though, you didnt really have to remember these proofs. The professor was also really open to questions and would explain anything confusingit was just quite fast if you wanted to keep up with every line.

The homework was challenging at times but manageable, and tests had some difficult problems, but the grading was really fair.
I think it is good overall, but one potential area of improvement is the originality of the content. Maybe I would like to see more insights than just the textbook definitions in lectures.
The lectures felt a bit imbalanced. Some had little material and others much more.

Strengths: Professor Wang's teaching style is clear and concise and the homeworks are helpful for understanding the material but aren't too much work. Weakness: measure theory just isn't that interesting.

One of the best mathematics courses I have ever taken. The problem sets were really interesting and really promoted a deeper understanding of the material; quite honestly the problem sets were really enjoyable. Exams were really tough, maybe that was just me.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: The first month of the course has a lot of overlap with math 305. Then the class moves very quickly through very important and difficult material. It is exhilarating but challenging to grasp the purpose of all the results.
yes
Don't take it with Wang. Maybe don't take it no matter who's teaching it if you feel like 305 has given you enough stuff to go straight to 325.
I found this course incredibly interesting and found the lectures incredibly engaging; I would most definitely recommend this course.
Yes, thorough overview of measure theory, taught really well, reasonable work and grading.
Yes, if they would like a thorough treatment of the topic. I learned a good amount.

Honestly, unless you're dying to learn measure theory or you're taking the analysis qualifying exam, there isn't really a good reason to take MATH 320. I liked Professor Wang and the the workload isn't bad at all, but overall the course content just wasn't interesting enough for me to enthusiastically recommend this course.
Yes, absolutely. The material was very interesting and structured in a very cohesive and logical manner. I like that the topics covered were given a highly abstract treatment.
Absolutely. I think the corse can provide fundamental insights for both abstract and applied research.
